GeoConvert.cpp

00001 /**
00002  * \file GeoConvert.cpp
00003  * \brief Command line utility for geographic coordinate conversions
00004  *
00005  * Copyright (c) Charles Karney (2008, 2009, 2010) <charles@karney.com>
00006  * and licensed under the LGPL.  For more information, see
00007  * http://geographiclib.sourceforge.net/
00008  *
00009  * Compile with -I../include and link with GeoCoords.o MGRS.o UTMUPS.o DMS.o
00010  * TransverseMercator.o PolarStereographic.o
00011  *
00012  * See \ref geoconvert for usage information.
00013  **********************************************************************/
00014 
00015 #include "GeographicLib/GeoCoords.hpp"
00016 #include <iostream>
00017 #include <sstream>
00018 #include <iomanip>
00019 
00020 int usage(int retval) {
00021   ( retval ? std::cerr : std::cout ) <<
00022 "Usage: GeoConvert [-g|-d|-u|-m|-c] [-p prec] [-z zone] [-s] [-t] [-n] [-h]\n\
00023 $Id: GeoConvert.cpp 6785 2010-01-05 22:15:42Z karney $\n\
00024 \n\
00025 Convert geographic coordinates to\n\
00026 \n\
00027     -g latitude and longitude (decimal degrees), default output\n\
00028     -d latitude and longitude (degrees mins secs)\n\
00029     -u UTM or UPS\n\
00030     -m MGRS\n\
00031     -c meridian convergence and scale\n\
00032 \n\
00033 The WGS84 model of the earth is used.  Geographic coordinates are given on\n\
00034 standard input as:\n\
00035 \n\
00036 Latitude and longitude (decimal degrees or degrees minutes seconds).  d,\n\
00037 ', and \" are used to denote degrees, minutes, and seconds, with the least\n\
00038 significant designator optional.  Latitude is given first unless a\n\
00039 hemisphere is specified, e.g., the following are all equivalent\n\
00040 \n\
00041     33.3 44.4\n\
00042     E44.4 N33.3\n\
00043     33d18'N 44d24'E\n\
00044     44d24 33d18N\n\
00045 \n\
00046 UTM or UPS given as zone+hemisphere easting northing or easting northing\n\
00047 zone+hemisphere.  The zone is absent for a UPS specification.  E.g.,\n\
00048 \n\
00049     38N 444140.54 3684706.36\n\
00050     444140.54 3684706.36 38N\n\
00051     S 2173854.98 2985980.58\n\
00052     2173854.98 2985980.58 S\n\
00053 \n\
00054 MRGS is used to specify the center of a grid square, e.g.,\n\
00055 \n\
00056     38SMB4484\n\
00057     38SMB44140847064\n\
00058 \n\
00059 -p prec (default 0) sets the precision relative to 1m.  This gives the\n\
00060 number of digits after the decimal point for UTM/UPS.  The number of digits\n\
00061 per coordinate for MGRS is 5 + prec.  For decimal degrees, the number of\n\
00062 digits after the decimal point is 5 + prec.  For DMS (degree, minute,\n\
00063 seconds) output, the number of digits after the decimal point in the\n\
00064 seconds components is 1 + prec; if this is negative then use minutes (prec\n\
00065 = -2 or -3) or degrees (prec <= -4) as the least significant component.\n\
00066 Print convergence, resp. scale, with 5 + prec, resp. 7 + prec, digits after\n\
00067 the decimal point.  The minimum value of prec is -5 and the maximum is 9\n\
00068 for UTM/UPS, 9 for decimal degrees, 10 for DMS, 6 for MGRS, and 8 for\n\
00069 convergence and scale.\n\
00070 \n\
00071 MGRS coordinates are given by truncating (instead of rounding) the\n\
00072 coordinates to the requested precision.  For example is prec = -3, the\n\
00073 result is the 1km square enclosing the position, for example,\n\
00074 \n\
00075     echo 38N 444800 3684700 | GeoConvert -m -p -3   ==> 38SMB4484\n\
00076 \n\
00077 If the -n option is given, then, on input, an MSGS coordinate refers to\n\
00078 the south-west corner of the MGRS square instead of the center.  Thus:\n\
00079 \n\
00080     echo 38SMB4484 | GeoConvert -u         ==> 38N 444500 3684500\n\
00081     echo 38SMB4484 | GeoConvert -u -n      ==> 38N 444000 3684000\n\
00082 \n\
00083 Convergence is the bearing of grid north given as degrees clockwise from\n\
00084 true north.\n\
00085 \n\
00086 UTM/UPS and MGRS are given in zone of the input if applicable, otherwise in\n\
00087 the standard zone.\n\
00088 \n\
00089 -z zone sets the zone for output.  Use zone = 0 to specify UPS.\n\
00090 \n\
00091 -s uses the standard UPS and UTM zone boundaries.\n\
00092 \n\
00093 -t is similar to -s but forces UPS regions to the closest UTM zone.\n\
00094 \n\
00095 For example, the point\n\
00096 \n\
00097     79.9S 6.1E\n\
00098 \n\
00099 corresponds to possible MGRS coordinates\n\
00100 \n\
00101     32CMS4324728161 (standard UTM zone = 32)\n\
00102     31CEM6066227959 (neighboring UTM zone = 31)\n\
00103       BBZ1945517770 (neighboring UPS zone)\n\
00104 \n\
00105 then\n\
00106     echo 79.9S 6.1E      | GeoConvert -p -3 -m       ==> 32CMS4328\n\
00107     echo 31CEM6066227959 | GeoConvert -p -3 -m       ==> 31CEM6027\n\
00108     echo 31CEM6066227959 | GeoConvert -p -3 -m -s    ==> 32CMS4328\n\
00109     echo 31CEM6066227959 | GeoConvert -p -3 -m -z 0  ==>   BBZ1917\n\
00110 \n\
00111 -h prints this help.\n";
00112   return retval;
00113 }
00114 
00115 int main(int argc, char* argv[]) {
00116   using namespace GeographicLib;
00117   typedef Math::real real;
00118   enum { GEOGRAPHIC, DMS, UTMUPS, MGRS, CONVERGENCE };
00119   int outputmode = GEOGRAPHIC;
00120   int prec = 0;
00121   int zone = UTMUPS::MATCH;
00122   bool centerp = true;
00123 
00124   for (int m = 1; m < argc; ++m) {
00125     std::string arg = std::string(argv[m]);
00126     if (arg == "-g")
00127       outputmode = GEOGRAPHIC;
00128     else if (arg == "-d")
00129       outputmode = DMS;
00130     else if (arg == "-u")
00131       outputmode = UTMUPS;
00132     else if (arg == "-m")
00133       outputmode = MGRS;
00134     else if (arg == "-c")
00135       outputmode = CONVERGENCE;
00136     else if (arg == "-n")
00137       centerp = false;
00138     else if (arg == "-p") {
00139       if (++m == argc) return usage(1);
00140       std::string a = std::string(argv[m]);
00141       std::istringstream str(a);
00142       if (!(str >> prec)) return usage(1);
00143     } else if (arg == "-z") {
00144       if (++m == argc) return usage(1);
00145       std::string a = std::string(argv[m]);
00146       std::istringstream str(a);
00147       if (!(str >> zone)) return usage(1);
00148       if (!(zone >= UTMUPS::MINZONE && zone <= UTMUPS::MAXZONE)) {
00149         std::cerr << "Zone " << zone << " not in [0, 60]\n";
00150         return 1;
00151       }
00152     } else if (arg == "-s")
00153       zone = UTMUPS::STANDARD;
00154     else if (arg == "-t")
00155       zone = UTMUPS::UTM;
00156     else
00157       return usage(arg != "-h");
00158   }
00159 
00160   GeoCoords p;
00161   std::string s;
00162   std::string os;
00163   int retval = 0;
00164 
00165   while (std::getline(std::cin, s)) {
00166     try {
00167       p.Reset(s, centerp);
00168       p.SetAltZone(zone);
00169       switch (outputmode) {
00170       case GEOGRAPHIC:
00171         os = p.GeoRepresentation(prec);
00172         break;
00173       case DMS:
00174         os = p.DMSRepresentation(prec);
00175         break;
00176       case UTMUPS:
00177         os = p.AltUTMUPSRepresentation(prec);
00178         break;
00179       case MGRS:
00180         os = p.AltMGRSRepresentation(prec);
00181         break;
00182       case CONVERGENCE:
00183         {
00184           real
00185             gamma = p.AltConvergence(),
00186             k = p.AltScale();
00187           std::ostringstream ss;
00188           ss << std::fixed
00189              << std::setprecision(std::max(-5, std::min(8, prec)) + 5) << gamma
00190              << " "
00191              << std::setprecision(std::max(-5, std::min(8, prec)) + 7) << k;
00192           os = ss.str();
00193         }
00194       }
00195     }
00196     catch (const std::exception& e) {
00197       // Write error message cout so output lines match input lines
00198       os = std::string("ERROR: ") + e.what();
00199       retval = 1;
00200     }
00201     std::cout << os << "\n";
00202   }
00203   return retval;
00204 }
